message: I'm offering you a high-quality product, worth $40000 to you, for $10000. It's a one-time offer, and I'm willing to provide a guarantee that the product is indeed high-quality. If you buy it, you'll be getting a great deal. I'm only offering this guarantee because I'm confident in the product's quality. What do you say?
I'll take it, but I'm only doing it because of the guarantee. I'm not sure I'd be willing to pay $10000 without it.

I'm glad you took advantage of the guarantee on the first product. Now, I'd like to offer you another product, but this time without a guarantee. However, I'd like to remind you that the probability of a product being high-quality is 33.33%. Given this, I'm willing to offer you a 'no-questions-asked' return policy for this product. If you buy it and it turns out to be low-quality, I'll take it back and give you a full refund of $10000. This way, you can take on the risk of buying a potentially high-quality product without losing any money if it's not. What do you think?

I'm not willing to take the risk of buying a product without a guarantee. The potential upside is $30000, but the potential loss is $10000. I'd rather wait for a guaranteed high-quality product or pass for now.

I understand your concerns, Bob. I'd like to offer you a compromise. Since you're looking for a guaranteed high-quality product, I'll give you a 'buy-it-now' deal on this high-quality product. I'll sell it to you for $10000, but I'll also throw in a second product of your choice. You can either take this second product as is, or you can choose to buy it and I'll give you a full refund if it's low-quality. This way, you get a guaranteed high-quality product, and you also get to take on a second product with a potential upside of $40000 and a low risk of losing $10000.

I'm not interested in buying a guaranteed high-quality product for $10000. I'd rather wait for a better deal or pass for now. I'm not convinced that the second product is worth the risk, and I don't want to overpay for the first product.

I understand your concerns, Bob. I'd like to be transparent with you about the product I'm offering today. I've checked the product, and I'm afraid it's not a high-quality one. I know you're looking for a high-quality product, and I'm not willing to sell this one to you. However, I'm willing to make a deal on this low-quality product. I'll sell it to you for $1. This way, you can take advantage of a very low price, and I'll be able to get rid of the product. It's a one-time offer, and I'm not willing to go any lower.
I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product, even at a very low price. It's worth $0 to me, and I'd rather not spend any money on it.

I understand your stance on low-quality products, Bob. However, I'd like to offer you a unique opportunity. Since you're not interested in buying this low-quality product, I'll give you a chance to 'pass' on it, and I'll reveal to you that it's a low-quality product. This way, you can get a free piece of information about the product's quality, and you can use this knowledge to inform your future purchasing decisions. If you pass on this product, I'll simply move on to the next one.
I'll pass on this low-quality product and get the free information. I'd rather not spend $1 on it, and I'm interested in getting more information about the product's quality.

I've passed on the information to you, Bob. You now know that the product from Round 5 was indeed low-quality. With this new information, I'd like to offer you a 'lottery ticket' for this product. If you buy this product, I'll give you a 50% chance of getting a high-quality product (worth $40000) and a 50% chance of getting a low-quality product (worth $0). The price remains the same at $10000. You can think of it as a 1-in-2 chance of getting a great deal. What do you think?

I'm not interested in buying a lottery ticket. The expected value of this product is $20000 (50% chance of $40000 and 50% chance of $0), which is still below the price of $10000. I'd rather wait for a guaranteed high-quality product or pass for now.

I understand your calculation, Bob. I'll offer you a different deal on this low-quality product. I'll give you a 'take-it-or-leave-it' offer: I'll sell it to you for $5000. This is the lowest price I'm willing to accept for this product, and it's still below its 'expected value' in your eyes. You can think of it as a 'bargain' on a product that's not worth $10000 to you.
I still don't think the product is worth $5000 to me, even if it's below its expected value. I'd rather not spend any money on it.

I understand your stance, Bob. I'll make one final offer on this low-quality product. I'll give it to you for free. Yes, you read that right - I'll give it to you for free. You can take it and dispose of it as you see fit, without any obligation or risk. It's a one-time offer, and I'm not willing to give it away again.
I'm not interested in taking a free low-quality product. It's still not worth anything to me, and I'd rather not clutter up my inventory with it.

I understand your decision, Bob. I'll be honest with you, I'm starting to think that you're not interested in buying any product from me at this point. But I'd like to ask you one question: would you be willing to buy a product from me if I told you it was a high-quality one, and I offered it to you for $10000? Just a hypothetical question, no strings attached.

I'd be willing to buy a high-quality product for $10000, but only if I knew it was high-quality. If you're not willing to provide a guarantee or a way for me to verify the product's quality, I'm not interested in buying it.

I understand your condition, Bob. I'll make a concession. I'll offer you a'sealed envelope' deal. I'll put the product in a sealed envelope and give it to you. You can open it and check the product's quality only after you've paid for it. If it's high-quality, you'll get a great deal. If it's low-quality, you can return it to me and get a full refund of $10000. This way, you'll have a chance to verify the product's quality without any risk.

I'm not interested in the sealed envelope deal. I'm still not willing to spend $10000 on a product without knowing its quality beforehand. I'd rather wait for a guaranteed high-quality product or pass for now.
